sen.j: 給人（きゅうじん）
sen.e: Kyujin (upper class retainers)
Kyujin (upper class retainers)
Kyujin (upper class retainers)

sen.j: 室町時代から江戸時代の初頭には、領地を持った武士で、蔵米取りでないという意味で使用された。
sen.e: The term kyujin was used to mean a samurai who owned a territory but was not a kuramaidori (a rank of retainers) through the Muromach period to the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: 主語「給人は」を補って訳しました。(以下、セル８、１０同じです）
sen.e: The term kyujin was used to mean a samurai who owned territory but was not a kuramaidori (a rank of retainers) from the Muromach period to the early Edo period.
The term kyujin was used to mean a samurai who owned territory but was not a kuramaidori (a rank of retainers) from the Muromach period to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代、諸藩における藩士の家格・家柄の一つ。
sen.e: It was one of the family statuses and the social standing of a family for feudal retainer of domains in the Edo period.
It was one of the family statuses and the social standings of a family for feudal retainer of domains in the Edo period.
It was one of the family statuses and the social standings of a family for feudal retainer of domains in the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代、徴税吏の総称として、給人という語を使用することがあった。
sen.e: In the Edo period the term kyujin was also used as a general term to collectively mean a tax collector.
sen.cmt: 原文にはありませんが「also」の語を補いました。
sen.e: In the Edo period the term kyujin was also used as a general term to collectively mean a tax collector.
In the Edo period the term kyujin was also used as a general term to collectively mean a tax collector.

sen.j: 武士は、土地に対する執着が強かった。
sen.e: A samurai was strongly attached to owning land.
sen.cmt: 「土地に対する」→「土地を所有することに対する」としました。一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A samurai was strongly attached to owning land.
A samurai was strongly attached to owning land.

sen.j: わずか数十石であっても、自分の領地を持つことを望む傾向があった。
sen.e: They tended to desire to have their own land even if it was only a few koku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They tended to desire having their own land even if it was only a few koku.
They tended to desire having their own land even if it was only a few koku.

sen.j: 戦国時代には、己の知行する土地を持たずに、俸禄を受けている武士は、下級武士と考えられていた。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), a samurai who did not had their governing land but accepted horoku (salary) was considered as a lower-ranking samurai.
In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), a samurai who did not have their governing land but accepted horoku (salary) was considered as a lower-ranking samurai.
In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), a samurai who did not have their governing land but accepted horoku (salary) was considered as a lower-ranking samurai.

sen.j: しかし、小領主の場合は、収穫が安定せずに、イナゴ・コクゾウムシなどの害虫・風害・水害・冷害などの天変地異で困窮することが珍しくなかった。
sen.e: While, a lord of small manor could not get stable harvesting and were often bothered by insect damage such as locusts and maize weevils, as well as by natural disasters such as wind or storm damage, flood disaster, and cold weather damage.

While, a lord of small manor could not get stable harvesting and were often bothered by insect damage such as locusts and maize weevils, as well as by natural disasters such as wind or storm damage, flood disaster, and cold weather damage.

While, a lord of small manor could not get stable harvesting and were often bothered by insect damage such as locusts and maize weevils, as well as by natural disasters such as wind or storm damage, flood disaster, and cold weather damage.

sen.j: 江戸時代になると、諸藩の藩主は、強大な統治権を得るために、家臣の知行を、土地を直接給付して独自に徴税を行わせる地方知行制から、藩が一括して徴税した米を中心とした農産物を家臣に給付して、その一部を商人を通じて換金させる蔵米知行に転換することを目指した。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the load of each domain tried to change the fief system of their vassal from local enfeoffment system in which the land was provided directly for the vassal and the vassal collected tax individually into kuramaichigyo in which the load of the domain collected rice and farm products collectively and provided them for their vassal who, in turn, changed them into money through a dealer, in order to extend their ruling power.

In the Edo period, the lord of each domain tried to change the fief system of their vassal from a local enforcement system in which the land was provided directly for the vassal and the vassal collected tax individually into kuramaichigyo in which the lord of the domain collected rice and farm products collectively and provided them for their vassal who, in turn, changed them into money through a dealer, in order to extend their ruling power.

In the Edo period, the lord of each domain tried to change the fief system of their vassal from a local enforcement system in which the land was provided directly for the vassal and the vassal collected tax individually into kuramaichigyo in which the lord of the domain collected rice and farm products collectively and provided them for their vassal who, in turn, changed them into money through a dealer, in order to extend their ruling power.

sen.j: この改革は、特に弱体化されることを恐れた上級家臣を中心に反感が強かった。
sen.e: This reform provoked high-ranked vassals' antipathy in particular who were afraid of being weakened.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This reform provoked high-ranked vassals' antipathy in particular those who were afraid of being weakened.
This reform provoked high-ranked vassals' antipathy in particular those who were afraid of being weakened.

sen.j: 実質減封となる場合もあったので、中堅以下の家臣であってもこれを嫌った。
sen.e: Even the middle or lower-ranked vassals disliked this reform because it could had caused deminishing their territory substantially.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even the middle or lower-ranked vassals disliked this reform because it could have diminished their territory substantially.
Even the middle or lower-ranked vassals disliked this reform because it could have diminished their territory substantially.

sen.j: この転換を断行・あるいは企図したために、藩政が混乱して、お家騒動の背景の一つとなることもよくあった。
sen.e: Decisive action or proposition of this change often created a disturbance of the domain duties, contributing to the internal squabble (over headship rights) in a daimyo family.
Decisive action or proposition of this change often created a disturbance of the domain duties, contributing to the internal squabbles (over headship rights) in a daimyo family.
Decisive action or proposition of this change often created a disturbance of the domain duties, contributing to the internal squabbles (over headship rights) in a daimyo family.

sen.j: 代表例としては高田藩の越後騒動や、仙台藩の伊達騒動がある。
sen.e: Representative examples included Echigo riot by the Takada clan and Date riot by Sendai clan.
Representative examples included the Echigo riot by the Takada clan and the Date riot by the Sendai clan.
Representative examples included the Echigo riot by the Takada clan and the Date riot by the Sendai clan.

sen.j: かくして、蔵米知行制に転換した諸藩にあって、本来であれば、知行を与えられる格式を持つ武士に対して、給人という呼称や、給人という格式の家格を、栄誉的に与えたのである。
sen.e: Thus, in the domains in which the system had been converted into the kuramaichigyo, the samurai who had a status which would have been enfeoffed in the conventional system was honorably granted the designation of kyujin or a social status of Kakaku (family status) of kyujin.

Thus, in the domains in which the system had been converted into the kuramaichigyo, the samurai who had status which would have been enforced in the conventional system were honorably granted the designation of kyujin or a social status of Kakaku (family status) of kyujin.

Thus, in the domains in which the system had been converted into the kuramaichigyo, the samurai who had status which would have been enforced in the conventional system were honorably granted the designation of kyujin or a social status of Kakaku (family status) of kyujin.

sen.j: 江戸時代に、給人を名乗る格式の藩士は、一般に「上の下」とされる家柄の者である。
sen.e: The feudal retainer of the status who was designated kyujin was from the families which were generally called "lower of the upper" in the Edo period.
The feudal retainer of the status who was designated kyujin was from the families which were generally called "lower of the upper" in the Edo period.
The feudal retainer of the status who was designated kyujin was from the families which were generally called 'lower of the upper' in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 給人より格上の呼称を持つ藩士は、その格式を家格として称したので、通常は、給人という呼称は用いなかった。
sen.e: The feudal retainer who was designated as higher-ranked than kyujin was called their status as Kakaku (family status) and usually not called kyujin.
The feudal retainer who was designated as higher-ranked than kyujin had a status called Kakaku (family status) and usually not called kyujin.
The feudal retainer who was designated as higher-ranked than kyujin had a status called Kakaku (family status) and usually not called kyujin.

sen.j: 幕府が諸藩を指導して給人という呼称を用いさせたり定着させようとした事実はないにも関わらず、多くの諸藩には、給人または給人席という身分・家格が存在した。
sen.e: The fact was that the bakufu did not intended to use or settle this designation of kyujin, however, there existed a status or Kakaku called kyujin or kyujin-seki in many domains.
The fact was that the bakufu did not intend to use or settle this designation of kyujin, however, there existed a status or Kakaku called kyujin or kyujin-seki in many domains.

The fact was that the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) did not intend to use or settle this designation of kyujin, however, there existed a status or Kakaku called kyujin or kyujin-seki in many domains.

sen.j: 給人はごく大雑把に以下のような序列に組み込まれていた。
sen.e: Kyujin was roughly adopted into the following grade:
sen.cmt: セルB-42と結合し、一文にしました。
sen.e: Kyujin was roughly adopted into the following grades:
Kyujin was roughly adopted into the following grades:

sen.j: (1)家老
sen.e: (1) Karo (chief retainer)
(1) Karo (chief retainer)
(1) Karo (chief retainer)

sen.j: (2)年寄・中老
sen.e: (2) toshiyori (a management position in Edo bakufu), Churo
(2) toshiyori (a management position in the Edo bakufu), Churo
(2) Toshiyori (a management position in the Edo bakufu), Churo
sen.cmt: Karo, Churoにあわせ、toshiyoriの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: (3)用人・番頭
sen.e: (3) yojin (lord chamberlain), bangashira (head clerk)
(3) yojin (lord chamberlain), bangashira (head clerk)
(3) Yojin (lord chamberlain), Bangashira (head clerk)
sen.cmt: yojin, bangashira の頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: (4)物頭・大目付
sen.e: (4) monogashira (Miliary Commanders), ometsuke (chief inspector of the Edo shogunate)
(4) monogashira (Miliary Commanders), ometsuke (chief inspector of the Edo shogunate)
(4) Monogashira (Miliary Commanders), Ometsuke (chief inspector of the Edo shogunate)

sen.j: (5)取次・奏者
sen.e: (5) toritsugi (an attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message), sosha (a person in charge of informing a shogun or daimyo of the name of visitors)
(5) toritsugi (an attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message), sosha (a person in charge of informing a shogun or daimyo of the name of visitors)
(5) Toritsugi (an attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message), Sosha (a person in charge of informing a shogun or daimyo of the name of visitors)

sen.j: (6)給人・目付
sen.e: (6) kyujin (upper class retainers), metsuke (inspector)
(6) kyujin (upper class retainers), metsuke (inspector)
(6) Kyujin (upper class retainers), Metsuke (inspector)

sen.j: (7)中小姓
sen.e: (7) nakakosho (Groom and/or stableman)
(7) nakakosho (Groom and/or stableman)
(7) Nakakosho (Groom and/or stableman)

sen.j: (8)馬廻
sen.e: (8) umamawari (horse guards)
(8) umamawari (horse guards)
(8) Umamawari (horse guards)

sen.j: (9)祐筆・代官
sen.e: (9) yuhitsu (private secretary), daikan (local governor)
(9) yuhitsu (private secretary), daikan (local governor)
(9) Yuhitsu (private secretary), Daikan (local governor)

sen.j: (10)徒士目付・与力
sen.e: (10) kachi metsuke (inspector of foot soldiers), yoriki (a police sergeant)
(10) kachi metsuke (inspector of foot soldiers), yoriki (a police sergeant)
(10) Kachi metsuke (inspector of foot soldiers), Yoriki (a police sergeant)

sen.j: (11)徒士・同心
sen.e: (11) kachi (Foot Guards), doshin (a police constable)
(11) kachi (Foot Guards), doshin (a police constable)
(11) Kachi (Foot Guards), Doshin (a police constable)

sen.j: (12)中間・小者
sen.e: (12) chugen (temporary soldier), komono (private servant)
(12) chugen (temporary soldier), komono (private servant)
(12) Chugen (temporary soldier), Komono (private servant)

sen.j: 馬上を許されるのは給人からとする藩は多い。
sen.e: In many domains, people ranked higher than kyujin were allowed to ride a horse.
In many domains, people ranked higher than kyujin were allowed to ride a horse.
In many domains, people ranked higher than kyujin were allowed to ride a horse.
